title: Indian Street Food
hero_image_alt: Collage of Pani Puri, Vada Pav, and Samosa
short_description: The heart of India's food culture. From spicy Pani Puri and Chaat to savory Kebabs and Rolls.
long_description:
Street food in India is not just a cheap meal; it's a way of life, a cultural phenomenon that transcends social boundaries. Every city, town, and village has its own street food culture, often centered around bustling markets, railway stations, and religious sites.

The most ubiquitous category is 'Chaat'—a family of savory snacks that originated in North India (Uttar Pradesh/Delhi) known for their complex flavor profile: spicy, tangy, salty, sweet, and crunchy all at once. Ingredients like potatoes, chickpeas, crisp fried dough, yogurt, and tamarind chutney are staples. Beyond Chaat, street food includes substantial meals like Vada Pav in Mumbai (the Indian burger), Chowmein (Indian Chinese), Rolls in Kolkata, and Idli-Dosa in the South. It is fresh, prepared largely in front of you, and incredibly affordable.

signature_dishes.name: Pani Puri / Golgappa
signature_dishes.short_description: Hollow, crispy fried dough balls filled with potato, chickpeas, and spicy tangy mint water. The undisputed king of street food.
signature_dishes.best_place_to_try: Everywhere (Elco Pani Puri in Mumbai is famous)

signature_dishes.name: Vada Pav
signature_dishes.short_description: Spicy potato fritter sandwiched in a bread bun with chutneys and fried green chili. The lifeline of Mumbai.

signature_dishes.name: Aloo Tikki Chaat
signature_dishes.short_description: Fried potato patties topped with yogurt, sweet tamarind chutney, mint chutney, and spices.

signature_dishes.name: Pav Bhaji
signature_dishes.short_description: A thick spicy vegetable curry (bhaji) served with soft buttered bread rolls (pav).

signature_dishes.name: Chole Bhature
signature_dishes.short_description: Spicy chickpeas (chole) with fluffy fried bread (bhature). A heavy North Indian breakfast.

top_restaurants.name: Haldiram's
top_restaurants.notes: Hygienic and standardized place to try almost all North Indian street foods.

top_restaurants.name: Elco Arcade
top_restaurants.notes: Famous for its hygienic Pani Puri.

best_markets_and_streets.name: Chandni Chowk
best_markets_and_streets.what_to_try: Paranthe Wali Gali, Natraj Dahi Bhalle

best_markets_and_streets.name: Sarafa Bazaar
best_markets_and_streets.what_to_try: Poha Jalebi, Bhutte ka Kees (Night Market)

street_food_highlights: Momos - Steamed dumplings (Tibetan infleunce) popular in Delhi/Metros.
Jalebi - Spiral sweet fried dough soaked in syrup.
Bhel Puri - Puffed rice tossed with chutney and veggies.
festival_foods: Ramadan: Kebabs and non-veg fry-ups near mosques.
best_months_to_visit_for_food: Winter (Nov-Feb) is best for enjoying hot street food.
recommended_precautions_for_travellers: Drink only bottled water. Avoid raw cut fruits/salads. Eat at busy stalls where food is cooked fresh hot.
how_to_order_guidelines: Specify spice level ('Teekha' for spicy, 'Meetha' for sweet).
cultural_significance: Street food is the great equalizer—rich and poor stand side by side to eat the same Pani Puri.
dining_etiquette: Eat standing up. Use the provided paper plates/bowls. Throw trash in bins.

top_places_to_experience.title: Delhi
top_places_to_experience.summary: The street food capital, especially for Chaat and Mughlai snacks.

top_places_to_experience.title: Mumbai
top_places_to_experience.summary: Famous for Vada Pav, Pav Bhaji, and Bombay Sandwiches.

top_places_to_experience.title: Indore
top_places_to_experience.summary: India's cleanest city with a legendary night food market (Sarafa).

suggested_itineraries: Golden Triangle of Street Food: Delhi (Chaat) -> Agra (Petha) -> Jaipur (Kachori).
seo_title: Indian Street Food Guide: Pani Puri, Vada Pav & Chaat
seo_description: Taste the real India. Guide to the best street food like Pani Puri, Vada Pav, and Kebabs across Delhi and Mumbai.
